18692953.review:
http://niveloculto.com/analisis-lovers-in-dangerous-spacetime/

Lovers in Dangerous Spacetime
Crítica

Hay juegos que están cargados de historias. Historias sencillas pero que llevan la pasión en cada línea de código. “Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime” es uno de esos juegos. El espacio es un lugar realmente peligroso, especialmente cuando el caos se desata ante la pérdida de las cuatro piezas del Reactor de Ardor. ¡De Ardor amoroso!

Lo que hacemos por amor…
Esta terrible pérdida ha tenido sus consecuencias, y es que hay muchos amiguitos entre constelaciones a rescatar. La fuerza del amor por rescatarles y la gratitud por tal hazaña te insuflan las fuerzas necesarias para avanzar.

¡Sois héroes! La galaxia está en tus manos para salvarla. Así que mirad con confianza a vuestro compañero y subid a la nave Chicle. Y sí, es de color rosa chicle. No pasará desapercibida entre el escenario, pero es que los héroes van pisando fuerte. Si decides jugar solo, el futuro te provee de dos criaturas, gato y perro a elegir, modificados genéticamente para que sean tus mejores aliados. Has de avanzar entre campañas que son cuatro constelaciones en total, con cuatro niveles en cada una sumado al quinto que será el jefe.

¿Preparados para embarcar?
Tienes a tu compañero que te dará fuerza en la aventura y una nave. Toca surcar el espacio en dos dimensiones en el que debemos tener una gran percepción del espacio, controlar el mapa, mantener la atención, conocer tus armas y lo que no son armas, dominar el estrés…

Es un juego realmente completo, muchas cosas que tener en cuenta. A medida que juegas compruebas que es un avance lento, de éxito incremental que resulta realmente satisfactorio, pero de ritmo frenético. No es posible aburrirse.

Entre esos factores has de tener en cuenta: las posibles colisiones, las órbitas de algunos cuerpos celestes pues cambiarán tus movimientos, las conductas de los enemigos que has de aprender, cómo el entorno es tu aliado en ocasiones, un amplio mapa a explorar, la salud de tu nave pues no has de malgastar los bonos de salud que encontrarás la misma estructura de la nave que has de conocer a base de moverte.

También encontrarás varios puestos de control: cuatro cañones, un cañón especial, un visualizador del mapa en su plenitud y por supuesto, el timón. A medida que rescates a (cinco como mínimo) amiguitos a la deriva, criaturillas que cambian dependiendo de la campaña que juegues, te abrirán portales a las fases siguientes. Además de escalar para subir tu rango y así desbloquear ventajas para tu nave. ¿Algunas de esas ventajas? Una curiosa nave adicional y muescas en las que puedes añadir turbos para los diferentes puestos de control, ¡y fantásticas combinaciones!

Entrar en la aventura de Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime requiere concentración, y sin duda la banda sonora favorece a ello. Especialmente útil a la hora de enfrentarse a los jefes, cuya estrategia vas asimilando a medida que avanzas en la campaña.

Si juegas solo, has de enfrentarte a un reto adicional. Aunque tengas a tu lado al mejor amigo del hombre, ya sea en forma gatuna o perruna, su inteligencia artificial es limitada. Obedece tus órdenes y es prácticamente un maestro armero, ¡pero no se puede tener todo! Hay ventajas que sacar del escenario que has de descubrir con tu ingenio, además de tu necesidad de estar pendiente de hacia dónde se mueve tu compañero para ayudarte a sobrevivir.


¿Aquello que realmente importa? El amor.
El amor para demostrar a tu compañero de aventuras que puedes comunicarte con él y vencer juntos a los enemigos. El amor por rescatar a todas las criaturas perdidas (y con los beneficios que allí se obtienen). El amor cuando extrañas a tu compañero cuando juegas en solitario, pues jugar en pareja con quien prefieras es una experiencia genial que no deberíamos perder. El amor por mapas que realmente fascinan. El amor por este tipo de juegos.

Lovers in Dangerous Spacetime es un título divertido, cargado de un humor muy sano, con un ritmo frenético y una curva de aprendizaje alta, con mensajes entrañables y una estética adorable. ¿Estresante? Mucho. Frustrante a veces, pero eso solo hace que quiera intentarlo con más fuerza.

Sin duda es un juego que me hubiera gustado crear para después disfrutar.

18591098.review:
Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime is a space style action shooter with heavy co-op elements. The game was released on Steam and Xbox One in September 2015 by indie developer Asteroid Base.

Whilst the game is focuses on the co-op element, the game can be played alone. You are in command of a space ship with a companion, in the single player this is a partly UI controlled pet, dog or cat, when playing co-op, the other player controls this character. The space ship has various seats that must be commanded in order for that part of the ship to be active, the seats consist of outer canons,  rotating gun, shields, maps and boosters; so that means only two parts of the ship can be active at one time. When playing single player, the UI controlled companion makes for a perfect rider of the ships weaponry as they can shoot targets even when you can't actually see them on the screen. I was quite happy to man the direction of the ship for the majority of the play through and just used the companion to switch between the more skill targeted seats. The actual aim in the game is to collect kidnapped space bunnies - these are spread out across the levels and some are not easy to find due to a fog of war feature also being included.  Whilst exploring and destroying other enemies, you will collect upgrades for your ships; these upgrades can be used on any of the ship's compartments, such as turning your canons into rail guns, or upgrading your ships boosters to go even faster.

Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime has a really neat graphic style - the neon art really shines through and actually fits in well with the gameplay. The bosses in this game look awesome; they look like something a child would drawer but have a real mature look about them. There isn't any voice acting though which I thought is a real shame given that there is a fair amount of text to be read. The soundtrack is stellar, and all of the sound effects are nice too. 

There are two levels of difficulties, easy and medium. I actually found the medium level to be really intensive, and actually had to drop the difficulty down on some of the levels - it's nice to see a game have challenging gameplay. This game takes a huge amount of skill to master it properly.  

Every level in Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime is randomly generated; meaning no play through is ever the same. There are four chapters, and each chapter consists of four levels with a boss fight at the end. All of the regular levels have the same aim as noted above, collecting the space bunnies/frogs/ducks and foxes.

I finished the game in just under four hours; so it is fairly short, but it has the added bonus of having the local multiplayer option which is absolutely huge - this ramps the replay ability up tenfold for me, given that all of the maps are randomly generated, you can play this game for hours on end with a buddy on the couch.  

Technically, this is a sound game; I was able to play on 4K resolutions, with in game options too.  A controller is recommended to play though; whilst keyboard and mouse is viable, you will definitely get more out of using a controller as the analogue stick makes a big difference when controlling the ship. The game does offer a fairly expansive tutorial too; and this gets you to grips with the controls very easily as it guides you through everything step by step. 

In conclusion; Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime is a top notch title; a really fantastic art style and with an innovative take on the co-op controls of a ship, this is special game. If you only plan on playing this game on your own, you may find the price tag of £10,99 to be a little much, but if you are going to be playing it on co-op with friends, then you are going to get more than your money’s worth out of this game. This is certainly a game to keep installed even after completing it!

[b][u] Tom's Score Card[/u][/b]
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
[b][u]4) Recommended[/u][/b]
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/completingthebacklog#curation]here[/url] - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime is a local co-op game wherein two players control a spaceship - or if you're playing alone, you and a companion AI. I have yet to actually play the game with a companion AI, but it's a good way to kill time when you have another friend to play with you at your place. The concept is simple: fly around the star system, save the inhabitants of that particular galaxy (so far, I've encountered bunnies, frogs, and foxes) collect the gears needed, and fight the boss, but with the brilliant way the co-op is implemented it becomes a very addictive and fun action game.

Definitely, definitely play with a friend for this one, as it's pretty much half the fun of this game when one of you is piloting the ship and trying to run around not punching each other off stations when the enemies are shooting at you. A good deal of strategy is needed, and you do have to be careful. But overall a fun game and extremely enjoyable.

The actual controls themselves make zero sense for a keyboard either, it basically treats WASD as the same as an analog stick, meaning pressing up makes the engine go up and stop at up, but pressing left means it stops half way around.
I can tell the dev has zero experience with PC games and, am not sure why they didn't just use one of unity's in-built control schemes if they don't know what they are doing.

It looks like an amazing experience, but not one worth bearing the iffy ai partner (yes it's awesome he's a cat, no it's not as awesome as my SO, who might also be a cat).

Until mouse and keyboard support is added, or more importantly proper co-op, I cannot recommend this game, unfortunatly.

18391975.review:
Lovers in Dangerous Spacetime:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~  

The power of the Ardor Reactor brings stability and happiness to the galaxy. Love is the flavour of everyday…. Interplanetary peace and love, should we say! Unfortunately, an error in the matrix (in the Ardor Reactor) has damaged the reactor. An explosion occurred and as a result it split in four pieces. But this is the least of your predicaments; the fault allowed the dark forces of Anti-Love to breakout and spread through the galaxy. Your goal is to recover the four pieces of the reactor to save the galaxy.  

Lovers in Dangerous Spacetime is a local co-op game setup in a space environment.  You and your AI companion (or a friend in local co-op) will be in command of a circular spaceship prototype to save the galaxy. The vessel has eight stations, four guns (north, south, east and west), one shield, one scanner, one super weapon and one engine station. All can be upgraded by collecting gems and you could end up with an interesting combination of weapons, from lasers to missiles or even a giant flail - how cool is that? You will have several missions per sector and will have to save a minimum of five folks (bunnies or frogs) to unlock the escape portal to finish your assignment. You will face a good mixture of enemies (including bosses) in well-designed levels. Also, every time you start a new campaign, levels will randomly generate themselves which adds so much in terms of replay ability. 

I would strongly recommend using a gamepad for this game as the keyboard setup is actually not the way to go. The game runs brilliantly and the artwork is cute.

Positives:
~~~~~~~~ 

-	Great co-op game
-	Challenging
-	Good artwork
-	Achievements
-	Trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~ 

-	Does not have online co-op

An incredible local co-op game! Fun, challenging and well executed. STOP READING… GO AND PLAY IT!!

9/10 

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

18310724.review:
Too many wonderful things to say; I'll give the short list of negatives first!

[list]
 [*]Online play would be nice, but this game definitely would lose much of its co-op charm if players were separated by an Internet connection.
 [*]The mechanics and gameplay are very solid and there's plenty of variety in enemies, environments, and obstacles, but a large amount of the game repeats this same formula many times over: explore a large map filled with enemies to collect enough friends to unlock the exit while gathering upgrades along the way. 
 [*]Gamepads strongly recommended. Keyboard (no mouse input) provides a cramped experience.
 [*]Some abrupt difficulty spikes, though generally provides a solid challenge throughout.
 [*]May trigger insecurities over one's own masculinity because hearts and bright colors and stuff.
[/list]

Beyond that, [i] Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime [/i] is a gem of co-op gameplay that really focuses on teamwork and communication in a way few other multiplayer or co-op games do. Its unabashedly cheerful art style, music, and atmosphere make this a fun and approachable game that delivers some decidedly challenging gameplay.

The upgrade system is intuitive and fun to experiment with, each of the levels progressively introduce new environmental mechanics that are easy to learn and a challenge to master. And everything from boss battles to gauntlet levels conclude with a rush of excitement. Don't let the cheerful visuals fool you: [i] Lovers [/i] offers plenty of challenge!

Best of all, even though [i] Lovers [/i] is best played with a partner, it's still plenty of fun to play solo!

Definitely worth the $15 investment!

18139782.review:
In June, I tried out this game at the Indie Game Revolution exhibit at the EMP Museum in Seattle, WA. When I first saw the demo at the EMP Museum, I was drawn to its bright, colorful graphics. Simple, cute, but not childish. I first thought that saving bunnies was a silly concept, but I soon realized that Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime took more strategy and skill than what first appears to the eye. 
Now that I've played through the first campaign on solo, and played a few levels of co-op I can definitely say that this game lived up to and exceeded all my expectations.

With just two nauts controlling the ship, gameplay can become quite hectic and challenging. But that's half the fun! In solo mode, you get a trusty AI dog/cat that you can command to man the different stations with you. They are quick to respond and generally shoot at what you want. (Sometimes they start shooting asteroids when there are enemies that need to be gunned down first!) 

Gameplay is challenging, and rewards players for exploring the map. If you find a "?" box on the map, shoot it open and you might get a gem you can use to power up a station! (Different gems and gem combinations change how your station is upgraded.) If you take extra time to save all 10 bunnies on a map (minimum of 5 unlocks the portal to the next level), you gain rank faster and can unlock more ships and gems slots for your ship stations. Customize your ship stations for your gameplay style!

Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime is advertised as a couch co-op game. I'm not sure why people are so angry that there isn't online co-op. The gameplay style of this game takes me back to the days of co-op arcade games, or cramming all my friends and family in front of one television as we all take turns trying to beat our own records on the old gaming consoles. Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime is one of those games that makes you want to invite friends over to beat together. I feel that the player experience would be different and not as special if this was not a local co-op game. But if there was an online co-op mode, you can bet this game would still be just as fun!

TL;DR - This game is quickly becoming one of my favorite co-op games. Highly recommended!! Pew pew!

18088295.review:
What can I say about Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime? It is a weird game but I had a blast with it.

Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime is one of the best couch co-op games that I have played recently. While you can play the game single player, I would recommend against it since it is such a great multiplayer game. Unfortunately the game doesn't have an online mode at this time so you will need to play the game locally.

What makes Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime such a great co-op game is that you need to work together in order to be successful. Your ship has many different stations and since you can only control one station at a time you need to work with your teammate in order to avoid destruction. The battles in particular can be really enjoyable as you are running all over your ship to get into a different station in order to destroy your enemies. 

The game has a couple small issues mostly revolving around sometimes having to spend too much time exploring, but they don't really hurt the experience. 

If you really like co-op games and the concept sounds at least somewhat interesting to you, I think you would really enjoy Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime.

Note: I received a free review copy of the game.

18081013.review:
Most of the time in gaming you are the sole hero who never needs anybody else, you can take out armies, command legions, and single-handedly save the universe. In Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime, your skill to work, and cooperate with somebody is exactly what will be put to the test in this addictive and fun action game. You can only man one post aboard a vast adorable spaceship, either man the guns or take the helm and maneuver through enemies. It's this dynamic gameplay that makes the game so simple but challenging at the same time. There are times where you both have to man turrets, abadon combat and just use shields and run for it. All this takes quite a bit of coordination. To help you are Space gems, wonderful little items that give the ship great customization as they change the way weapons, shields, and the helm work. Add on to that randomized maps, unlockable content, adorable bunnies, a great artstyle, and you've got an amazing title. Single players need not dismay, as Lovers does have the option to bring a trusty space cat or dog. Keep in mind though that for maximum enjoyment of this game, playing with a friend is optimal. Just remember that relationships/friendships can be hard, add on to that your life depending on somebody else and things get dicey! Buyers beware this will put your heart to the test!

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/ceEUsDgkteY
I hope you enjoy!

LOVERS IN A DANGEROUS SPACETIME is one of the rare occasions I directly bought a game after seeing the trailer. And it was totally worth its full price!

This game has an amazingly imaginative art style that I haven't seen in any other 2D game before. Somehow Asteroid Base have managed to design something that looks cute, sharp, vibrant and colourful, yet doesn't feel childish or cringeworthy.

This is without a doubt one of the best coop-games I have ever played. Especially because it allows you to have lots of fun right from the start. Unlike some other games, where it only really opens up if you reached a certain level or got a particular upgrade.

My only complaint from the 3 hours I have played thus far is that the upgrade system can be a bit unclear at times. Why is it that I lose my upgrades between worlds? I suppose this is because of balance reasons, but this isn't communicated to the player in any way.

18036402.review: If you are looking for a great couch co-op game, especially since there have been a dearth of them lately, I highly recommend this game. I'm always on the lookout for good couch co-op and this fits the bill! Many co-op games don't seem to be built around that idea so they just feel like an afterthought and are a bit boring. This game does not feel that way! You'll have lots of fun yelling at your "lover" frantically trying to decide the best strategy. The game is essentially the platforming version of the tabletop game Space Alert. Strategy and skill is required to reach various stations that operate your ship such as weapons and thrust. The style is adorable and highly amusing; it is saccharine but tongue-in-cheek. I highly recommend this game.

18036212.review: It's the best parts of my favourite games all in one. And some how still seems to be completely original. Best game ever, ever, ever!

18032250.review:
Como o nome sugere, o jogo tem uma premissa hippie bizarra: num futuro distante, foi construído o Reator do Ardor, uma máquina capaz de utilizar o Amor para gerar energia. Esse reator era protegido por uma organização chamada Lovers.

Até que um erro na matriz explodiu o reator, fazendo com que força sombria do Anti-Amor se espalhasse pela galáxia. O resultado disso: bichinhos fofinhos foram enjaulados!

Você fará parte do esquadrão dos Lovers, e utilizará a única nave sobrevivente do desastre para tentar recuperar os quatro pedaços do Reator do Ardor, para reconstruí-lo e salvar o universo.

O jogo é composto de 4 campanhas sequenciais, cada uma delas contendo 4 fases, e uma fase de chefe. As fases são procedurais, isto é, a cada visita, terão layout gerado aleatoriamente, aumentando bem a rejogabilidade.

Possui uma gama de progressões permanentes, e também algumas temporárias, válidas apenas durante cada campanha.

O objetivo primário para poder passar de uma fase é resgatar bichinhos-espaciais cósmicos para poder progredir. Cada fase possui um total de 10 bichinhos enjaulados, variando os bichinhos entre coelhinhos, sapinhos, gatinhos ou passarinhos, com fome a campanha. Não que isso faça diferença alguma.

Desses 10, são necessários apenas 5 para poder passar de fase. Os outros 5, você até poderia deixá-los mofando e seguir sua aventura - ao preço apenas de prejudicar a progressão de nível.

Ao passar de nível, você terá 4 linhas de upgrades, e cada linha possui uma exigência de nível mínimo para ter seus upgrades acessíveis, respectivamente níveis 2, 3, 5 e 8. Os upgrades englobam melhora nas estações das naves, permitindo o uso de duas jóias simultaneamente (que será explicado mais adiante), e também desbloqueio de naves.

Ao iniciar uma partida, você começará escolhendo o seu personagem. Inicialmente, você terá apenas 3 personagens disponíveis, e poderá liberar mais 5. A maioria dos personagens são liberados automaticamente ao concluir cada campanha.

Ao escolher uma campanha, você poderá escolher sua nave. A nave inicial disponível é a Chiclete Zero. As outras naves que liberará com nível são a Banana Split e a Gelatina, cada uma com seu próprio layout e peculiaridades de funcionamento.

Joias são a progressão temporária principal durante uma campanha. Você pegará jóias ao abrir presentes nas fases, encontrados aleatoriamente espalhados pelo mapa.

São três tipos de joia: de poder, de raio e de metal. Ao pegar uma das jóias, você poderá colocá-la em qualquer uma das estações da nave: escudo, motor, canhão Yamato e cada uma das torres de armas. Fazendo isso, a joia ficará sobre a estação, e imediatamente alterará o funcionamento daquela estação.

Ao passar de nível e liberar os upgrades que permitem duas jóias em cada estação, cada par de jóias resulta num outro efeito para a estação: joia de poder com joia de metal, joia de poder com joia de raio, joia de raio com joia de metal, ou duas jóias de um mesmo tipo. A ordem das jóias não faz diferença.

O jogo tem duas dificuldades: normal e casual. No modo casual, enfrentará menos inimigos, que terão menos vida, e você tem mais vida. Certamente é um modo recomendado ao jogar com alguém que não seja muito bom em jogos em geral. Isso porque a dificuldade normal já é bem difícil, exigindo muita coordenação para sobreviver, com muitos momentos de aperto.

A jogabilidade do jogo é muito única: você verá sua nave como que em uma visão de raio X, e deverá andar com seu personagem até umas de suas estações. Ao adentrar numa estação, você passa a controlá-la.

Ou seja: a nave possui até 8 estações, e apenas duas delas estarão ocupadas por vez. Resultado: as tarefas precisam ser divididas, e você por vezes terá que correr entre uma estação e outra para reagir.

Ao jogar sozinho, você terá um fiel pet para te auxiliar a controlar as estações da nave. Ele não possui autonomia: você deverá segurar a tecla N, que fará o jogo ficar em câmera-lenta, e em seguida escolher quais das estações ele deve ocupar. A única estação que ele não ocupa é a do controle da nave.

Você enfrentará uma série de inimigos distintos, cada um com seus padrões de movimentação e ataque. A maioria dos tiros deles podem ser destruídos ao tomarem um tiro seu.

Caberá a você dividir sua equipe entre as estações: ocupar duas estações de combate, para matar rapidamente os inimigos? Deixar um dos membros no escudo, para garantir a proteção da nave? Ou deixar um dos membros no motor, para ter mobilidade no combate?

Durante a fase, você encontrará caixas voadoras, e atirando nelas, pegará seus conteúdos. Quando com o símbolo de interrogação, os pickups podem conter jóias variadas. Há também pickups que dão dados de localização de bichos enjaulados, facilitando assim que você os encontre. Você poderá ainda encontrar corações, que irão reparar sua nave.

As fases em geral são retangulares, e possuem um relevo diversificado, onde você precisará contornar muitos obstáculos. Para auxiliar na localização de objetos e amigos enjaulados, o primeiro recurso é o mini-mapa, localizado no canto inferior esquerdo do mapa. Nele, você poderá facilmente identificar inimigos, itens, amigos enjaulados e outras coisas mais, te dando uma visão maior do que a da tela.

Além disso, você poderá utilizar a estação de mapa de sua nave para abrir o mapa, permitindo uma visão total de sua fase, de partes exploradas, não exploradas, e também de amiguinhos a serem resgatados, caso você tenha pego algum pickup.

Ao localizar um ou mais bichos numa jaula, em geral, basta quebrar a jaula com tiros, que os bichos virão até sua nave automaticamente. Porém, fique atento: uma série de eventos pode acontecer nesse processo.

Cada campanha costuma ter uma temática, e dentro de casa fase delas, você poderá encontrar diferentes objetos e variações no ambiente.

O jogo possui gráficos simples, porém extremamente vivos, com cores fortes e muito contraste. O traçado dos personagens faz parecer que é um desenho de Hanna-Barbera - especialmente alguns dos chefes.

A música eletrônica acaba por contribuir com o clima louco do jogo. Os sons são bem repetidos e desesperadores, sejam os alarmes, os tiros, ou mesmo os gritos dos bichos enjaulados. O resultado é uma atmosfera bem alucinante, que mal dá pra respirar e prestar atenção em cada um dos elementos.

O jogo conta com cooperativo local para 2 jogadores, sem suporte a drop-in. Para jogar de dois, o segundo jogador deverá entrar na tela de seleção de personagens, entrando no lugar do pet do jogador 1.

Como o jogo possui poucos botões e não utiliza o mouse, é possível inclusive que dois joguem no mesmo teclado: desde que não haja um limite baixo de teclas no dispositivo. Naturalmente, o ideal é ter ao menos um joystick.

Seja pra quem gosta de jogos de nave, seja pra quem gosta de cooperação com muita ação independente do gênero, Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime garante muita diversão com um desafio considerável.

As campanhas não são muito extensas, levando aí cerca de 4 horas para finalizar as quatro, mas é uma medida boa para um jogo local, especialmente considerando que a ação não pára.

Como as fases são procedurais, o jogo nunca fica enjoativo. Somando isso às progressões, você terá motivos de sobra para refazer as fases e campanhas - além de se divertir, é claro.

O modo casual também é muito útil para poder dividir o jogo com pessoas que não são acostumadas com jogos, como namorada ou crianças.

Análise completa em http://www.poepra2.com.br/analise/lovers-in-a-dangerous-spacetime/

18028854.review:
Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime is an awesome game that forces you to co-operate with a real or AI friend.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hv8UYI6bXFM
The game shares a few similarities to FTL or Guns of Icarus, in the sense that you need to navigate from different parts of your ship in order to survive. Although, because you're only 2 crew members, it's much more intense.

In singleplayer, you can tell your AI pet what to take control of. It's very competent and so can use anything but piloting the ship. You need to do that, however you're also free to let go of the wheel and command your shields, or turrets. In co-op, anyone can take control of anything. It's in 2 player mode that the game shines, in my opinion.

Your main objective is to free the set amount of bunnies in each level. Once you've done that, the level exit will open. If you choose to stay and uncover the entire map, look for all possible upgrades and free all bunnies, then each level can take you between 15-30 minutes. On top of that, each time you start a new campaign, levels will be randomly generated, adding infinite replay value.

The game becomes incredibly satisfying as you upgrade your ship. Different gems can be used to modify different parts of the ship. For example. putting a pink gem on you turret will make it a triple barreled machine gun. Putting a blue gem will turn it into a yo-yo like wrecking ball. Putting a pink gem on you shield will make it cover more of your ship. Putting a yellow gem will make it smaller, but deflect projectiles. You can even combine gems to create different powerups. As you rank up. you can also unlock different ships that have different attributes. It makes the game so much fun.

The art style is incredibly cute, and the music is cool.

Overall, I think this game is awesome! Give it a try

18002686.review: The team at Asteroid Base Inc. have absolutley outdone themselves. Just one look at the screen is all it takes to recognize ABI's articulate attention to detail. The heart melting & cutesy visual style of this game coupled with LiaDS's intense co-op experience keeps me coming back for more. At first glance this game may seem as though it could be short, however, the ever changing game dynamics you encounter within each solar system keeps the game fresh and challenging. Not only will the player encounter new obsticles and enemies, but the biomes in each universe provide new reasons to rethink your tacitcs, loadouts (power-ups), or even the ship you wish to spread the love with. Including the tutorial, there are 5 systems to venture through that each hold several levels, which once again may leave you with a feeling that there isn't enough. Though I'll challenge that notion by asserting that each level can take anywhere from 15 minutes to a half an hour or more. Having said that, the game also provides a challenging normal difficulty that leaves room for the players to improve upon their tactics and teamwork. I'm excited to feel the love on hard mode ._. 10 out of motherloving 10.

18001368.review:
LiaDS is a very cool game. You are on a mission to restore love to the galaxy in your spaceship, with either one player and an AI helper, or local co-op. It has a pretty unique gimmick, in that you must move your characters from station to station in order to control parts of the ship you're flying. What this means in practice is that most of the time one person will be flying the ship, while the other moves between the guns and the shields defending you. In special circumstances both players will have to man the defenses while the ship idles.

The graphics are super cutesy, and they belie the absolutely punishing difficulty of this game. You'll need a competent second player to match the excellent performance of your AI pet, who zips between stations at your command and just kicks butt on the regular. But when things are in a groove and the chaos is all around you, the game is incredibly satisfying. And the good number of power-up combinations keeps things interesting. Just be prepared for the occasional frustration as the hordes of attackers wipe you out yet again.

The unique mechanic of only being able to control one station at a time makes this game feel like a mix between FTL: Faster Than Light and a shoot-em-up. It's honestly inspiring to see such an innovative gameplay concept these days, when it sometimes feels like all the genres possible have been conceived already. Which is to say, I can see this as the foundation of a new genre, much like Minecraft single-handedly brough the crafting genre into existence. It's that good. I found it intriguing enough that I bought it at only a small discount, which is incredibly rare for me.

EDIT: Having played this game a few more hours, my estimation of it continues to increase. Rather than getting stale, it's becoming more entertaining the deeper I go. The power up combinations hold some amazing surprises, the music is fantastic, and the game is so well put together and so polished, it's like the distilled essence of joy to play it. I'm willing to call it the best game of the year right now.

17974445.review:
How does a PC game in this day and age, specifically a co-op game, not offer multiplayer over internet? I was so incredibly excited to play this game with a friend of mine who has similar tastes in games because the co-op looks amazing. However since the game limits co-op to being on the same physical machine using controllers or one keyboard that won't happen. My friend has 3 kids and we play games from 10-12 at night after his kids are in bed. Why oh why not offer an online play option? Isn't the idea of 2 copies of the game being sold for 2 people to play appealing from a business standpoint?

The lack of ability to play with a friend (unless they're physically next to me) is a big downer. However the game is still so incredibly fun it's worth the buy. Though to be fair realize that it's a single player title unless the other person is physically there with you.

17964851.review:
This game is great, the art style, music, and gameplay is very fun and unique.  I highly recommend this game to anyone that has a friend to play with locally.  

For singleplayer though, I suggest you look elsewhere.  I suggest you watch some reviews first before making this purchase.

From a singleplayer perspective, the gameplay does not flow smoothly; it feels very "stuttery".  There is quite a bit of micromanaging in this game, during battles you:  command pet to a position, move your ship, move your shields, hop onto a turret to shoot a bit, and then repeat.  Throughout the fight you're not feeling engaged in the combat, it's more about moving around so you don't get hit and let your pet do the shooting.  Overall it is just not fun, well to me anyways, to just move a ship around and not being involved in the combat while the A.I. does everything else.

If this were just a singleplayer game only, this game would get a "thumbs down", but since there is local co-op and everything about this game is very unique from art style to (co-op) gameplay, this will get "thumbs up".

17961345.review:
[u] Summary: [/u]
Lovers in a Dangerous Space Time is definitely more enjoyable with a friend, as you both work back and forth to take advantage of the unique gameplay on segmented functionality regarding shields/navigation/firing. While the AI follows your orders rather well, the lack of him being able to navigate can lead to gameplay that has pacing problems in that case. The core firing and enemy variety does help the game rather well, and the aesthetic is rather nice without being in your face. Upgrade system is rather nice and interesting in the way it combines weapons. Basically, if you're looking for a local co-op experience to play with a friend in a shoot em up nature: this works rather well. 

[b] Gameplay Footage and Video Review: http://youtu.be/5JxyEvsr5q8[/b]

[u] Lists: [/u]

[b]+:[/b]
[list]
[*] Local Co-Op sets up gameplay that reinforces communication with your partner and creates an environment to get the chat going rather well. 
[*] Like the upgrade system and the different combinations that can be created from it. Things like the laser mace are interesting in their combination.
[*]Aesthetic is nice without being too in your face with colors. The best laid back neon style I've seen in a while.
[*] Soundtrack is soothing, not too over the top and fits the game rather well. Good laid back feel. 
[*] Enemy variety works with different ways of having to deal with them. 
[*] AI is competent in firing, and in particular in using the shield against the right enemy at the time.
[/list]

[b]-:[/b]
[list]
[*] Really would have done well to have online multiplayer. Again, sensitive to the amount of programming that it would take, but I really think it would have taken this game, which is obviously co-op focused, to the next level.
[*] Single player does lack in compared to local co-op experience due to the lack of AI being able to navigate, although understandable given the amount of work to program pathfinding would be. 
[*] Game can feel samey rather quickly. In particular, the game's pace is rather slow. Action players may find the game hard to get into. 
[/list]

17958574.review:
I loved this game from the moment I saw it years ago, but playing the full fleshed out version is even better. The best way to play is with a friend because of the constant need to shuffle around the different stations. Despite its adorable art style the game can be surprisingly difficult, and I often found myself finishing levels by the skin of my teeth. You can cruise a bit in early levels, but if you don't pay attention you can quickly find yourself on the way to exploding.

The single player is good too because you get to command an AI cat or dog! The AI does a good job of killing enemies, manning the shields etc. The only limitation is that they can't drive which is understandable since it would take additional commands to tell the pet where to steer towards.

The new levels also are always adding new mechanics which mix up the formula and keeps things from getting stale. Water planets, ice planets, enemies that can only be defeated by ricochet-ing shots from a star etc. And also unique boss battles for each section.

There's a nice progression system of upgrades where by saving more bunnies (or frogs) you get more points towards upgrades that unlock stations that can fit more gems to modify your weapons and eventually unlock ships with different layouts. I feel bad for leaving any of the space bunnies behind so I'll definitely be trying to go back to save more of them in future playthroughs. 

Unique premise, lovely art style, and really kickass soundtrack. One of the most unique games you'll play, highly recommended!
